comments.commentTitle: Excellent Service from Colombus Travel, Quito, Ecuador.
comments.commentBody: My wife and I recently returned from travel to the Galapagos Islands,from January 10,2011 to January 22,2011, flying from Miami to Guayaquil, Ecuador in order to have the most convenient connection to Aero Gal Airlines,which flies non-stop to and from the Galapagos Islands from there. I want to give high praise to Columbus Travel,www.galapagosisland.net and to the extremely efficient and excellent service we received from their sales representative, VeronicaDarquea, vdarquea@cloumbusecuador.com. She arranged our flights on Aero Gal, a four-night boat cruise and a thee night stay at the Royal Palm Hotel on Santa Cruz Island. She responded to all of our requests for information with quick replies and with clear and correct information. Every aspect of the itinerary she set up for us went perfectly well. Veronica Darquea has excellent communicating skills and 10 years experience as a Galapagos travel consultant. Working with Columbus Travel and Veronica Darquea was a most enjoyable experience.

comments.commentTitle: Coastline Cottages - Most Romantic Place in the World
comments.commentBody: We reserved a studio with Coastline Cottages to renew our vows on beautiful Kauai. The Upper Studio at Turtle Cove Cottage couldn't have been more perfect. Saw lots of turtles. Rainbows and gentle waves, cool breezes too. We will definitely return - tomorrow if I had my way.

Interesting purchase in light of Director Thomas Campbell's expertise in renaissance tapestries. I wonder what role he played in the acquisition?

To refer to Perino del Vaga as merely one of Raphael's pupils does him a great disservice.
May God bless Hélène and Richard Gere who is supporting wonderfully Hélène and Hélène's activities.

What I take away from this research is that the best family dynamics exist where both parents have a relationship with their kid. The smaller the child, the more that relationship necessarily involves caregiving. How you divide the housework, yardwork, paperwork, auto care, extended family responsibilities and the other stuff that eats at your time, is interesting, worth discussion, but it has nothing to do with how successfully you interact with your kids.

I DO think what is important is that BOTH parents desire equal time with the kids, seize it when they can, and have enough hours left in the day so that BOTH have ample opportunity to develop a relationship with the kids. Kids are always growing, constantly changing, and I think the good parents are those that have enough time with their kids to stay up to speed with where they are and what they need.

If you ask me, the biggest threat to that is not the way chores are divided, its the total number of hours per week that the parents are working. My experience, and observation: As you exceed 70 hrs/wk for one earner, or 100 hrs/wk for 2 earners with childcare arrangements, it gets harder (not impossible, just harder) to stay up to speed with your kids, and its harder to both get in enough downtime so that you come to your kids EAGER to be with them and with enough patience to work through problems as they arise.

The French sensibly avoid the concept of "equality" as in "everybody doing the exact same thing".

They instead speak of "égalité" as in "everybody has balanced responsibilities and accomplishments".

So if one parent loves to make dinner and the other loves to vacuum and both like to take the kid to the park, then responsibilities are shared and "égalité". But they are not equal.

As Madeleine L'Engle's Meg Murray observed in "A Wrinkle in Time: "Like and equal are not the same thing at all."

It may not make headlines, but it is the truth.

I'm going to say it, there are an awful lot of American families where any semblance of coparenting is impossible because American men have been raised to not take care of others.  How common is it for a woman to list their husband as their extra child?  Some like this, it's a way to keep power, most of us don't.  I have without judgment tried to hand the reins over to my husband on many areas.  Perhaps dinner is the clearest example, it works out best if he is responsible for dinner.  For over a month I refrained from comment, dinner some nights never got made, kids rummaged in cabinets eating snacks, dinner came sometimes at 7pm, 8pm, 4:55pm, and other random times.  Dinner was mostly comprised of whatever leftovers could be heated in a microwave, and my husband is actually a fairly good cook.  Eventually he gave up when the kids flew into utter rebellion.  And on it goes, it reminds me of when you give someone a responsibility and they mess it up so that hopefully you'll take it from them and they can get back to what they want to do.  Coparenting is a beautiful idea, and if you have a kind, motivated, committed guy, wow!  There's only about 5 of them in the US though.

Am so glad my kids are grown up.  Somehow we we did it without all the books and experts peering down at us.  Only in the states could this over parenting or under parenting happen.  Or who is most equal or who does the most work.  What a bore.  Travel south to Mexico and Central America and further and you will find just getting the kids a decent diet and getting them off to school is about all they can handle and as far as i am concerned, that's good enough.  Get over yourselves parents in the states.  Europe is much more relaxed and they, parents,  don't worry so much about who does what, or are they overly enamored with their kids or themselves.

I was walking in Capitola, CA along the wharf, and I saw a lot of kids with dads.

Several were fishing for supper.

The weak economy means that anyone who can get a job holds a job and others pitch in. Child care is really costly and the first expense to be cut when there's unemployment / underemployment.

The reality is that people have always traded off looking after the kids. Peasants cutting wheat or pulling a plow took their kids with them during the day and sat them in a haystack. Women and men carried their children on their backs as they worked. During the industrial revolution, when men were fired so the textile mills could hire women and children for half the wages, men were left to look after the kids.

It happens over and over again. This is the result of economic cycles in a wage-based economy.

A "family" means you pull together and do what it takes to survive as a family. If it means mom's got a good job and dad stays home to look after the kids, then that's the right thing to do for them. It's a serious duty and an honorable one - not a fatuous choice.

Thousands of years of patriarchy cannot be undone without a struggle! I found that my pro-feminist husband/co-parent was totally in favor of equality--he just didn't notice some stuff that needed noticing (e.g., we're at a party and someone has to watch the kids--we can't both be chatting cheerily with the adults). So of course there was tension. If I had thought it was simply "my job" to watch while he chatted, then there'd have been less. Though we struggled, I don't regret it at all, and I am sure he doesn't either. Our now-adult kids have close relationships with both of us, and neither has any concept of what is inherently "men's work" vs "women's work."

I would much rather have my mother in the delivery room with me than my husband. My mother has given birth five times--twice naturally, and three times with epidural. She knows the ropes.

My husband, on the other hand, while a wonderful fellow, gets incredibly stressed out when he sees me in any sort of pain or distress which, in turn, stresses me out. I'm sure, though, that other husbands are very well-equipped to provide support for their wives in the delivery room.

Bottom line: different strokes for different folks. The "right answer" depends upon the strengths and preferences of the individuals involved.

What a weird coincidence. I just put up a poll on my blog this morning asking which was better for families, having one parent home with the kids, or two parents who work part time.

My husband and I have take turns being primary breadwinner at different points in our marriage. In general, we do best as a couple when we're both working and both taking responsibility for childcare and household stuff, although it certainly takes good communication to make it work. The only caveat is it didn't work when we were both working FULL TIME at the same time.

Katrina
http://WorkingMomsBreak.com

This topic exemplifies America's misguided and misplaced fascination with anything termed "research". More evil has been done, esp. in the field of education, because we take as gospel some little blip of an effect in some little pathetic paper, preferably written by an Ivy-or-equivalent-educated-or-employed academic, who regressed a few variables on a few other variables and came up with some silly, but "statistically significant" result. Tan-tara -- policy implications up the wazoo. Please people, these are small, mean (as in average) effects, in (relatively) teeny samples, based on opportunistically collected data.

Take courage from the brave Egyptians: trust your instincts, revolt! Go divide up your child rearing tasks just as you think will make you happy -- and it they don't, try, try again. The causality goes something like this: if it makes you (your family) happy, it is right for you; NOT, do it like this and ON AVERAGE, you (your family) will be happy.

#26 Brenda writes: A fetus is not a baby. For those who believe that any combination of sperm and egg = life....

Brenda, what exactly is a fetus, if not a human being in its early stages?

Thank you Amy and Marc for providing a much better interpretation of the study than the media was providing. I agree, any type of pseudoequality it not really true equality, and is an arrangement ripe for arguments. Only when both parents truly equally share the care of their child can their be fewer arguments about parenting - both parties are fully competent, either is more superior to one another, therefore there's really no bickering and arguing to be done over the little things. ESP is not about splitting everything 50-50, it's the concept that dad and mom are equal caregivers to their child. The burden it reduces off the traditional mom role and the involvement that it provides the traditional dad role makes the arrangement incredibly fulfilling for both parties. Having done it for 15 months and counting, my husband and I could not have imagined a richer life, and will protect this wonderful arrangement aggressively - we wouldn't have it any other way.

And to the dad who does not think it's possible to have true ESP while mom is breastfeeding, think again. BF is an incredible time-consuming task, there's so much dad can do in terms of bottle and parts washing, drying, packing, fridge milk management, etc. In terms of bonding, bottle feeding with expressed milk creates just as close of a bond as BF itself. After BF for the first 9 months, guess who my 15 month old has a preference for? Hands down, it's all about Dada. I'm not jealous, in fact I think that preference for my husband was well earned, kudos to him for being a "real" parent to our son and creating such a special bond with him so early in his life.

There are other forms of scams than having a property be non-existent; they're not quite as costly or clear-cut as what happened to FT, but when a property isn't as advertised, you still feel scammed. My husband rented us a small property in the UK through VRBO a few years ago. As I later found, VRBO is merely a listing site whose only "service" is to provide gushing, professionally written descriptions of the properties, with no verification of the listers' assertions. So, the very lived-in property we arrived at in a lovely UK town had 2 of its listed 5 beds virtually inaccessible (in a tiny attic, reached through a ceiling trap door!), garbage greeting us in the kitchen, and throughout the week, a non-functioning kitchen boiler. But, since we'd paid for the reservation by costly bank transfer (!) I now realize how lucky we were that this shelter existed at all. On the other hand, we had to stay there...! Upon return, I  tried to provide honest feedback on the VRBO site, only to realize that no comments could be posted without the owner's review and approval... Ha! Fool me once...

No such mention Paul...I have both Edu and Clark as (very) late subs in my pecking order, and Edu ahead of Clark.  None of my starting combos, or even second choices places either of them in the top 4 in the middle, Edu first sub in a 4-4-2 if a 4-4-2, then Clark sixth man.  Take a second look.  The "he" when I say he brings serious competition to owning the middle is Jones.

Greyhound can feel stale compared to the other carriers, but it's a great option when you don't know exactly when you'll be leaving. While they will gladly sell unlimited seats to any of their buses (i.e., they don't seem to cap sales at capacity) they also don't mind if you board a bus at a different time. So if you're playing your weekend by ear, it's nice. And for $5 more you can get Priority Boarding, meaning they let you walk to the front of the line and board right away. It is a pretty nice perk.

Also, the Bolt double-decker buses are fun to ride in (although they have limited standing headroom and no carry-on luggage space) but if you're riding upstairs, you'd better hope your driver is minding the clearance signs on bridges -- a google search for double-decker bolt bus accidents will yield some grizzly photos.

One correction: You shouldn't assume that a request for a bank transfer is a scam. In Europe, bank transfers are used much more widely (and with less expense and hassle) than in the U.S.. Most individual landlords don't have Paypal accounts and aren't likely to have a way to accept deposits or rent payments by credit card.

In my opinion, the easiest way to minimize your risk of being scammed is to use a service like HomeAway.com, a rental agency, or (in some countries) the booking service of a local tourist office instead of looking for unvetted ads on Craigslist. My wife and I have rented vacation apartments and cottages in Europe via mail, fax, and (more recently) the Internet since the 1980s, and we've never had a problem.

I agree with an earlier posted comment. We used airb&b a few months ago on a trip to Vienna and were very satisfied. The apartment we stayed at looked exactly as was shown on their website. We were visited by the owner before our depature to Slovakia.after five nights and we felt that we were returning home when we returned to Vienna.for the remaining three nights.

The apartment probably does exist; it's just not owned by whoever posted the Craigslist ad. A friend of mine (and fellow vacation rental owner) discovered last year that someone had lifted her property's photos and descriptions and put them on Craigslist. Before reporting them to the site and the police, she posed as a traveler and responded to the ad, and the response to her e-mail inquiry included a believable rental contract and very good English. The only indication of a scam was the insistence on wire transfers.

Alas, I disagree that this is more likely to affect budget travelers. My friend's property might be a great deal in the Hamptons, but the scammers still stood to make thousands from anyone who fell for it.

I should point out that some legitimate rentals still don't accept credit cards, but they are fast becoming the minority. And I agree with all the advice you've given, except perhaps the bit about visiting before you book. Depending on the time of year, I sometimes have to refuse requests for a visit from an inquirer, because our rental is occupied by guests whose privacy I am not willing to intrude. There are honest reasons that a rental owner might refuse a visit.

I'm very sorry you got scammed, but thank you for sharing so that others can learn from this. From the other side of the transaction, I can tell you that honest rental owners are delighted to interact with informed travelers.

This shows just how cut off even educated Americans are from the Middle East. Our news is censored and yet we are supposed to find our way out of the morass.  But why worry, as Bismark observed, God takes care of children, drunks and the U.S. of A.
intelligent.informative... programming attributes too often 'a best kept secret'

We switched from Cox cable (after 25 years) to DirecTV last year and the only downside was realizing I was an idiot to not do it a decade earlier. It is better in every conceivable way.

But, I had no idea that the progressive Link TV channel even existed until we got DTV, and they broadcast a nightly half hour Al-Jazeera news program. But, since the crisis began, they have pre-empted much of their regular programming and have been carrying Al-Jazeera virtually non-stop.

We watched it for hours on Saturday and were amazed by the depth of the reporting, and the contrast between the Brit journalists that work there and the goofballs we have become used to.

Just for a lark, we decided to check out the US news channels to see how they were handling the crisis coverage. MSNBC was airing the equivalent of wall-to-wall dated repackaging of "Dateline". They will never be taken seriously as a news channel until they stop turning into TruTV every weekend.

The breathless Wolf Blitzer on CNN was arguing with someone over some incidental fact, and we had a horrible flashback to both Iraq wars, when Wolf merely parroted everything the Pentagon handed him, without ever seeking affirmation that what he was broadcasting was true.

Fox News seemed to be spending most of the time explaining how valiantly Condi Rice and the Bush administration tried to bring democracy to Egypt, a grand plan that apparently had been squandered by Obama's election.

Thank gawd for Al Jazeera, Link Tv and DirecTV. Reality can be such a comfort in times like this.

I've been without a TV for the past couple years, but when I read a Fcebook post from an Egyptian friend in Cairo on Tuesday, there was really only one immediate and viable place to view what was happening on the ground. I've been watching and tweeting practically non-stop since. In addition, English language blogs from the AlJazeera correspondents (in Washington and throughout Egypt), as well as foreign policy views caught initially from Tweets and Egyptian activist perspective helped to flesh out mine, and many other vantage point on the Egyptian revolution. What emerged was an amalgam of information that moved at a rapid pace that a traditional resource shouldn't be expected to fulfill. A people's perspective, one can argue, should come from many sources to be dynamically analyzed.
